item.title: By: Jim Vanderveen
item.dc:creator: Jim Vanderveen
item.description:
Hey dude,
I was checking my ping history. It seems like having the ping enqueue timestamp in the header of the "Ping Details" (<a href="http://www.pingqueue.com/history/ping/?blog_ping_uuid=c6a301af-4bee-11da-8ec9-000cf1c93f2f" rel="nofollow">example</a>) page would be useful for checking the queue delay.
Jim
item.content:encoded:
Hey dude,

I was checking my ping history. It seems like having the ping enqueue timestamp in the header of the “Ping Details” (example) page would be useful for checking the queue delay.

Jim

item.title: By: SonicChicken weblog » Blog Archive » New ping service is live!
item.dc:creator: SonicChicken weblog » Blog Archive » New ping service is live!
item.description: [...] PingQueue is Joseph’s recently-announced ping service. Details of this service are available via the links in this entry. But in a nutshell, the advantage of this service is that ping requests are queued up–this sounds like a disadvantage, but the response time for adding a request to the queue is much faster than synchronously pinging multiple services. [...]
item.content:encoded: […] PingQueue is Joseph’s recently-announced ping service. Details of this service are available via the links in this entry. But in a nutshell, the advantage of this service is that ping requests are queued up–this sounds like a disadvantage, but the response time for adding a request to the queue is much faster than synchronously pinging multiple services. […]
